lexer

Class Lexer

  • java.lang.Object
    • lexer.Lexer

  • public class Lexer
extends java.lang.Object
    The Lexer class is responsible for scanning the source file which is a stream of characters and returning a stream of tokens; each token object will contain the string (or access to the string) that describes the token along with an indication of its location in the source program to be used for error reporting; we are tracking line numbers; white spaces are space, tab, newlines

      Constructor for Lexer where it initializes the token table

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

      • newIdToken

        public Token newIdToken(java.lang.String id,
                        int startPosition,
                        int endPosition,
                        int lineNo)
        newIdTokens are either ids or reserved words; new id's will be inserted in the symbol table with an indication that they are id's
        Parameters:
        id - is the String just scanned - it's either an id or reserved word
        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the token begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the token ends
        lineNo - is the line number in source file where the token is
        Returns:
        the Token; either an id or one for the reserved words

      • newNumberToken

        public Token newNumberToken(java.lang.String number,
                            int startPosition,
                            int endPosition,
                            int lineNo)
        number tokens are inserted in the symbol table; we don't convert the numeric strings to numbers until we load the bytecodes for interpreting; this ensures that any machine numeric dependencies are deferred until we actually run the program; i.e. the numeric constraints of the hardware used to compile the source program are not used
        Parameters:
        number - is the int String just scanned
        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the int begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the int ends
        lineNo - is the line number in source file where the token is
        Returns:
        the int Token

      • newFloatToken

        public Token newFloatToken(java.lang.String number,
                           int startPosition,
                           int endPosition,
                           int lineNo)
        Float tokens are inserted in the symbol table without converting the strings to numbers
        Parameters:
        number - the float String just scanned
        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the float begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the flat ends
        lineNo - is the line number in source file where the token is
        Returns:
        the float Token

      • newCharToken

        public Token newCharToken(java.lang.String number,
                          int startPosition,
                          int endPosition,
                          int lineNo)
        Char tokens are inserted in the symbol table
        Parameters:
        number - the char just scanned
        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the char begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the char ends
        lineNo - is the line number in source file where the token is
        Returns:
        the char token

      • newScientificNToken

        public Token newScientificNToken(java.lang.String number,
                                 int startPosition,
                                 int endPosition,
                                 int lineNo)
        Scientific numbers are inserted in the symbol table without converting the string into float
        Parameters:
        number - the scientific number String just scanned
        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the scientific number begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the scientific number ends
        lineNo - is the line number in source file where the token is
        Returns:
        the scientific notation token

        public Token makeToken(java.lang.String s,

                       int endPosition,
                       int lineNo)
        build the token for operators (+ -) or separators (parens, braces) filter out comments which begin with two slashes
        Parameters:

        startPosition - is the column in the source file where the token begins
        endPosition - is the column in the source file where the token ends

        Returns:
